artcl_titl_en: 금호 주가조작 고발사건 관련자 조사 마무리

artcl_ctt:
? From the Justice Ministry... 
Prison inmates will be allowed to grow their hair... starting the first half of next year.
? The decision comes as part of government efforts to enhance prisoners'' rights.
Currently, inmates are prohibited from growing their hair any longer than three centimeters... except for well-behaved prisoners... who''re allowed to let their hair grow to up to five centimeters.
Other changes include the removal of handcuffs during interrogations or trials... and a ban on newcomers reporting their entry... an act... which the Ministry says... has been the leading cause of prison violence.?
artcl_titl: #Ministry to Allow Inmates to Grow Long Hair#
artcl_titl_en: #Ministry to Allow Inmates to Grow Long Hair#

artcl_ctt:
? The Korea Stock Exchange is looking towards the new millennium with high hopes.
After a banner year, major securities firms are predicting the KOSPI will rise even higher next year.... to as much as 1-thousand-600 points.
Shim Miryung brings us the outlook.

? 19-99''s stellar performance is expected to continue in the new millennium.
Led by a strong showing in internet and information technology shares... some analysts are even predicting the Korean Composite Stock Price Index to surge above the one thousand 500 mark.
The over-the-counter KOSDAQ is also expected to fuel the rise... the index soaring from this year''s 270... to over 360 next year.
However, there is the risk that some high-tech firms may be unable to live up to expectations.... and die out.
The fate of such firms will be decided at the end of March... when their profits are unveiled.
Experts advise investors to venture into the market during the first quarter of next year... when the bull run is likely to continue amid expectations of an economic recovery.
Rebounding corporate sales and an upgrade of Korea''s sovereign credit rating are other factors likely to fuel the surge.
However, shares will likely start to drop after April''s general elections... with the government likely to pursue belt-tightening policies.
Another rally is expected though, during the third quarter... and Hyundai Securities predicts the index to climb over 1-thousand-400 points at the end of next year.
?On average, local brokerage houses project the KSE to hover between the 1-thousand-200 and 1-thousand-300 level.
Semiconductors, TFT-LCDs, animation and environment-related shares are expected to emerge as the frontrunners... along with Internet, telecommunications and financial issues.
However, the pharmaceutical and construction industries are not expected to fare as well... their shares are likely to suffer in the year 2000.
Shim Miryung, Arirang TV.?

? The government''s also planning to provide greater support for the lower-income class... in the coming year.
? The Ministry of Finance-Economy says... 2-point-3 trillion won... or about two billion dollars has been earmarked for that purpose.? 
That''s up 38 percent... from this year''s budget.
Two new items have been added on... for the first time...
5-point-5 billion won for the homeless... and 250 billion won to help pay for the education of students from low-income families...
400 thousand middle and high school students are expected to benefit from the measure.
More than half of the total budget will go toward guaranteeing the basic livelihood of the people... including that of prison inmates around the country.?
artcl_titl: More help to the needy#Sub-budget increase by 38 percent#
artcl_titl_en: More help to the needy#Sub-budget increase by 38 percent#

artcl_ctt:
? Meanwhile... the KOSDAQ market will have a wider trading band... when it re-opens for the New Year.
? The price range will be expanded from the current 12 percent... to over 15 percent.
In addition, the maximum number of simultaneous hits on its computer system... now at 900-thousand... will soar to five-million.
The limited capacity has been blamed for delaying transactions... and hindering the growth of the market.?
artcl_titl: 코스닥 가격 제한 폭 올려 # Changes to KOSDAQ in 2000 #
artcl_titl_en: 코스닥 가격 제한 폭 올려 # Changes to KOSDAQ in 2000 #

artcl_ctt:
? Along with the Korea Stock Exchange... the over-the-counter Korea Securities Dealers Automated Quotation... closed for 19-99 this afternoon.
Both markets will re-open at 10 a-m... on January 4th.
Here... in the meantime... is a look back at their stellar performance over the past 12 months.

? For the first time ever... the combined value of firms listed on the Korea Stock Exchange and the KOSDAQ markets... have exceeded the annual Gross Domestic Product.
According to the Bank of of Korea and the K-S-E... G-D-P for the year is estimated at just under 439-trillion won.
Market capitalization is slightly higher... with the figure posting 445-trillion won... as of this Monday.
The Korea Stock Exchange enjoyed a superb year... with total market value soaring by nearly 150 percent over the year... to 342-trillion won.
And it was a phenomenal year for the over-the-counter KOSDAQ market.
97 firms were newly listed this year... and total capitalization skyrocketed more than 12-fold.
As of Monday... total market value of KOSDAQ firms stood at 103-trillion won.
? From a global perspective... the International Federation of Stock ? Exchanges said the capitalization of global markets went up 32 percent for the year... as of the end of November... and total market value is higher than the global G-D-P estimate of 30-point-1-trillion dollars... put out by the International Monetary Fund.
Suk Min Arirang TV.?
artcl_titl: 증시 시가총액 올해 GDP보다 많다#Market capitalization exceeds GDP#
artcl_titl_en: 증시 시가총액 올해 GDP보다 많다#Market capitalization exceeds GDP#

artcl_ctt:
? Hopes are also high for the local stock markets.
By the end of this year 2000... analysts are expecting the KOSPI will hit 16-hundred.
This... after the markets wrapped up 19-99 on a very merry note... this past Tuesday.
After their doors closed... some people sat down and punched numbers to see just how much the markets earned in 19-99.
Here''s what they found.

? The stock market ended a banner year on a high note... with the benchmark Korea Composite Stock Price Index hitting a yearly high of 1028-point-0-7.
That''s a surge of nearly 75 percent... compared to the beginning of 19-99.
The over-the-counter KOSDAQ market also enjoyed phenomenal growth... with the key index soaring more than 340 percent over the year.
And for the first time ever... the combined value of firms listed on the K-S-E and the KOSDAQ market... exceeded the country''s annual Gross Domestic Product.
According to the Bank of of Korea... G-D-P for 19-99 was estimated at just under 440-trillion won.
Market capitalization was slightly higher... with the figure posting 445-trillion won... as of December 27th.
The total market value of K-S-E-listed firms surged by nearly 150 percent... to 342-trillion won.
Over on the technology-heavy KOSDAQ market... 97 firms were newly listed in the past 12 months... and total capitalization skyrocketed more than 12-fold.
As of this past Monday... total market value of KOSDAQ firms stood at 103-trillion won.
After an extended new year''s break... trading will resume at 10 a-m on January fourth. ?

? And praying for peace on the Korean peninsula...
? Seoul''s Ewha Womans University hosted a unique event yesterday... to feed the hungry in both South and North Korea.
Some 500 people... including Seoul Mayor Koh Gun... faculty and students... gathered for the rice cake festival... which had all the participants making and cutting some twenty tons of Ga-rae-dduk (가래떡).
That''s the rice cake used in the traditional New Year''s soup.
Made from rice donated by various civic groups... the rice cakes will be distributed around the nation and sent to the North... early next month.
What''s more... the hand-made rice cake turned out to be the longest in the world... at 350 meters.
Organizers of the charity festival... plan to have the rice cake recorded in the Guiness Book of Records.?

? With the economy on the rebound... small and mid-sized firms are finding it easier to secure bank loans...
Total loans to these firms... as of last week... surpassed a hundred-trillion won... or 83-billion dollars.
? The Bank of Korea says... this year alone... the amount jumped by almost 20-trillion won.
Analysts explain... economic activity''s picking up... and a growing number of companies are looking to expand their business.
In addition... banks these days... are giving out more loans to companies with growth potential... than they did two years ago at the height of the country''s financial crisis.?
artcl_titl: 은행의 중소기업대출#Bank loans to small businesses tops 100 trillion won#
artcl_titl_en: 은행의 중소기업대출#Bank loans to small businesses tops 100 trillion won#

artcl_ctt:
?
? The rival political camps are working to arrange a summit early next month... between President Kim Dae-jung and opposition leader Lee Hoi-chang.

? Fierce competition''s expected among telecom service providers next year... with the introduction of a free Internet phone service.

? And... last weekend''s killer storms have so far killed 79 people in Europe... and the number''s likely to rise.?

? Hope you''re enjoying your Tuesday.  Welcome to Arirang News... for December the 28th.
A possible sign of thaw in the country''s political arena...
We start this hour with that story.?

? Hello and welcome to Newsroom Update.

? 37 companies under court mediation or receivership have been ordered to shut down by the government.
The call came after creditors, along with the Financial Supervisory Service... decided the companies have no chance of survival.
The non-viable firms account for around half of all companies under court mediation or receivership.
The FSS also plans to take similar measures for non-viable companies... currently subject to creditor-led debt rescheduling... or the workout programs.
The creditor banks predict around nine such firms will be ordered to close... in the first half of next year.

? Prosecutors will summon Kumho Group chairman Park Jung-koo (박정구) today... in connection with their probe into alleged share price manipulation.
Overnight... they questioned his brother Park Sang-gu (박상구), President of Asiana Airlines.
The prosecution is trying to establish whether the Kumho Chairman and his brothers... used insider information... to illegally embezzle profits.
They allegedly sold shares in Kumho Tire to the group''s petrochemical unit last April... for a profit of 920-million won.

? In Europe... the death toll from last week''s storms has risen to 79.
More than half of the victims were in France... where 1-and-a-half million people are still without electricity.
Paris officials say... it will take at least three years and billions of dollars to rebuild the city.
Several of the city''s cultural monuments were damaged... and experts say they''ll need around 80 million dollars to repair them.
Meanwhile... three Korean mountaineers were helicoptered down from the French Alps.
They were stranded on the mountains since Sunday... when the killer storms roared through the region.

That is all for now.
Thanks for watching.?

? Going over to western Europe now...
The death toll from last week''s killer storms now stands at 79.
? More than half of them were in France... where 1-point-5 million people are still without electricity.
The Paris government says... it''ll take at least three years... and billions of dollars... to rebuild the capital.
Several cultural monuments were damaged as well... and to repair them... experts say they''ll need up to 80 million US dollars.
Meanwhile... three Korean mountaineers were helicoptered down from the French Alps.
They''ve been stranded on the mountains since Sunday... when the deadly storms... with freak winds... tore through the region.?
artcl_titl: 유럽 살인폭풍 피해확산#Europe reeling from storms#
artcl_titl_en: 유럽 살인폭풍 피해확산#Europe reeling from storms#

artcl_ctt:
? Now to a rosy outlook for the Korean economy.
The Bank of Korea predicts... among other figures... a GDP growth rate of seven percent... next year.
Here''s a closer look at the projections.

? It won''t be this year''s double digit growth... but the central bank expects Korea to grow another seven percent in the coming year.
The Bank of Korea says... ? exports will continue to rise in the new year... helping Korea to enjoy another trade surplus... although... it will be half of this year''s at 11-point-5 billion dollars.?
Based on customs calculations... Korea will be in the black by 16 billion dollars.
? Consumption will charge ahead another 7-point-5 percent... while facility investment will leap 15-point-5 percent.
Next year also looks good for the construction sector.?
After contracting sharply this year... business will pick up... to put the industry back in the positive terroritory in the five percent range.
And on inflation... Korea is looking at posting 3-point-1 percent next year.
? In the meantime... researchers say... Korea will wrap up 19-99... with a gross domestic product of 10-point-2 percent... thanks to strong growth in the final months.? 
The B-O-K''s head researcher explains this year''s astounding performance is largely due to inventories being cleared... a factor the economy will have to do without next year.?	
?
 The government now predicts next year''s G-D-P growth rate to reach six percent...
?
 That''s one percent higher than its earlier forecast.
And during the time... inflation is likely to be lower than initial expectations... staying in the two percent range.
Authorities also believe the current account surplus will exceed 12-billion dollars... while the unemployment rate will fall to... four-point-five percent.
The revised outlook reflects the government''s economic plans for the new year... which the Ministry of Finance and Economy will unveil early next month.?

?Meanwhile... on Monday night... President Kim hosted a dinner for three former presidents... discussing state affairs as the year closes out.
Also on hand... were the chiefs of the legislative, judicial and administrative branches.
Ex-presidents Choi Kyu-ha, Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Taewoo... along with Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil, Chief Justice Choi Jong-young and National Assembly Speaker Park Jun-kyu were at the Chongwadae meeting.
But former president Kim Young-sam turned down the invitation... citing personal reasons.
President Kim explained Korea''s economic recovery process... and asked the others to play a constructive role in rooting out regional antagonism.?
artcl_titl: KTW DJ Hosts Dinner for Predecessors
artcl_titl_en: KTW DJ Hosts Dinner for Predecessors

artcl_ctt:
? That''s all from us at this hour.  We''ll see you back here later tonight... with more news.
Thanks for watching.?

? Kumho Group chairman Park Jung-koo was summoned by Seoul district prosecutors today... in connection with allegations of stock price rigging.
? This wraps up their investigation into the four Kumho Group brothers...
One''s been cleared of any involvement in the case...
The other two... Park Sam-koo, President of Asiana Airlines... and Chan-koo, head of Kumho Petrochemical... had been questioned earlier.
Of them... the prosecution says... the president of the petrochemical division... will be indicted without physical detention... for violating stock trading laws.
He''s alleged to have used inside information about a pending merger between Kumho Tires and Construction... AND bought and sold stocks in the tire company last year... thereby reaping illegal profits.
Prosecutors plan to close the case after announcing the results of their probe on Thursday.?

? Meantime... the President has pledged minimal government intervention in the stock market next year.
? His comments came during yesterday''s ceremony... marking the year''s final day of trading at the Korea Stock Exchange.
As the first president to attend this ceremony... Kim also said the government would work to ensure fair and open transactions.

And speaking of transactions...
? The benchmark index wrapped up 19-99 at a yearly high of one thousand-28.
That''s a rise of 22 points from Monday... ? which analysts attribute to expectations of another bull run early next year.
253 million shares exchanged hands... worth 4-point-7 trillion won.
But losers led winners 5 to 3.
? Over on the forex market... the Korean currency tumbled... on active dollar buying by local banks... 
It weakened nine won... to drop to 11-42 and-a-half.?
artcl_titl: Tuesday markets #Tuesday stock and f/x markets#
artcl_titl_en: Tuesday markets #Tuesday stock and f/x markets#

artcl_ctt:
? A possible breakthrough in the on-going labor dispute at the state-run Korea Minting and Securities Printing Corporation.
? The company''s labor and management agreed last night... to sell the Okchun(옥천) plant... and move all of its facilities... to the Buyeo(부여) plant.
They also agreed on a four percent pay cut.
Both parties say... the changes will help reduce costs... and enhance operations at the state mint.?
artcl_titl: 조폐공사, 옥천 제조창 매각#State mint to sell off Okchon plant#
artcl_titl_en: 조폐공사, 옥천 제조창 매각#State mint to sell off Okchon plant#

artcl_ctt:
? Meanwhile... the President''s scheduled to give a national... year-end address this morning.
? During his speech... he''s expected to thank Koreans for their sacrifice and cooperation... in overcoming the foreign exchange crisis of late 19-97.
But at the same time... President Kim will likely warn against complacency... saying the so-called IMF era may be over... but there''s still ways to go before the economy regains its former strength.
The President''s message will be televised live nationwide in three hours... at 10 A-M... Korea Time.?
artcl_titl: 김대중 대통령 내일 특별담화#DJ year-end message tomorrow#
artcl_titl_en: 김대중 대통령 내일 특별담화#DJ year-end message tomorrow#

artcl_titl: 여.야, ''독도 호적 이전''에 강력 대응 촉구
artcl_titl_en: 여.야, ''독도 호적 이전''에 강력 대응 촉구

artcl_ctt:
? Hello.  I''m Ahn Junghyun in Seoul... welcoming you to Arirang TV''s special live coverage of the President''s Year-End Remarks.
There are less than 3 days left of the year 19-99... and in just a few moments... we''re going to hear what President Kim Dae-jung has to say at this point in time... when we''re about to bid farewell to what''s been a remarkable year for Korea.
Now... we say ''remarkable''... because there have been some major developments and accomplishments over the past 12 months... that simply cannot go unnoticed... especially on the economic and diplomatic fronts.
Today... President Kim will be talking about some of them himself... how he evaluates... and feels about them.
And we''re also likely to hear just how the President''s preparing for the turn of the millennium... and what his new year resolutions may include.

So without further due... let''s go over to the presidential office of Chongwadae... where President Kim''s just about ready... to deliver a special year-end message to the people of this country.?

? So why don''t we talk a little more now... about what issues, in particular... are expected to be covered by President Kim''s year-end address today.

No doubt... the President will be looking back at the past 12 months of efforts to lift the economy out of what was dubbed the nation''s worst crisis since the Korean War half a century ago.
He''s widely expected to convey a message of thanks to the Korean people... for the cooperation and sacrifice they''ve shown in the process of the country''s economic recovery.
If we would recall... President Kim recently declared... Korea was safely out of the so-called IMF era.
But today... he''s also expected to warn against complacency... pointing out there''s still a long way to go... before Korea can completely regain its former strength.

Then there will be some mention of the President''s diplomatic accomplishments.
Now... President Kim''s been hailed as the most diplomatic Korean leader... and as if to prove that... he spent 19-99 making a number of overseas trips... solidifying Seoul''s ties with the world''s superpowers... and forging a stronger alliance with other countries in the Asia-Pacific region.
The biggest achievement, though... would be the support President Kim''s won from the world over... for his engagement policy towards North Korea... as well as all the positive signs of a thaw in inter-Korean relations.
Of course... the past year did see its share of ups and downs... when it comes to North Korea developments... whether with South Korea or with other parts of the world.
The down side includes things like missile threats... the inter-Korean naval clash in the West Sea... the detention of a South Korean tourist to North Korea''s Mount Kumgang.
But the end results were mostly positive.
Pyongyang struck a deal with Washington to halt missile tests... it''s moving to improve ties not only with the U-S, but also with Japan, Australia and other world neighbors... the Mount Kumgang tourism project celebrated its first anniversary... economic cooperation between the two Koreas is picking up speed... and there have been active sports and cultural exchanges between the South and North.
And as President Kim has said before... the year 2000 and the new millennium are expected to bring many more positive changes in inter-Korean developments.

Contrary to these economic and diplomatic successes... the domestic political front has been rather rocky... with endless partisan bickering and high-profile scandals.
And today... President Kim just might offer his apology for these unfortunate incidents... along with his firm resolve to right the wrong in the coming year.
Such a resolve is already reflected in the list of the Kim Administration''s new year policy guidelines, as announced last week.
Under the theme "New Millennium, New Hope"... Seoul''s policies next year... will focus on five key areas...
Among them... national unity''s given top priority... followed by completion of administrative reforms... realization of a knowledge-based society... economic advancement... and promotion of inter-Korean cooperation.
And toward achieving the number one goal... that is, national unity... President Kim and his government will be making an all-out effort to root out regional antagonism... a factor that could very well determine which direction April''s general elections will take.?

? Good Morning.
It''s seven o''clock Tuesday, December twenty-eighth.
Korea is starting the day under a thick cloud cover... which could result in either rain or snow this morning.
By the afternoon though... skies are expected to clear up.
Checking the temperatures... they''re higher this morning compared to yesterday''s... ranging between minus one and four degrees.?

? That is our report this morning.
Please join us back here soon.
And in the meantime... thank you for watching!?

artcl_titl: 흡연 피해 공동 소송 인지대 유예
artcl_titl_en: 흡연 피해 공동 소송 인지대 유예

artcl_titl: 자민련 박태준 총재, 소선거구제 수용 시사
artcl_titl_en: 자민련 박태준 총재, 소선거구제 수용 시사

artcl_ctt:
? The National Assembly has passed the Integrated Broadcasting Law... ending five long years of partisan wrangling.
The law calls for the establishment of an independent broadcasting committee... with the authority to give licenses to newcomers in the field... ? and form broadcasting policies.
Struck from the revised bill, though... is a controversial clause... under which employees of KBS and its affiliates would be sentenced to one-year in prison... if they were found to have leaked confidential information... or refused to carry out punitive measures imposed by the broadcasting committee.?

? That was President Kim Dae-jung... delivering a live... year-end message from Chongwadae...
And as expected... his speech offered both... a look back on the past year of developments and accomplishments... and a look forward into the new year and the new millennium.
Now... in about three days'' time at the very start of the year 2000... President Kim''s scheduled to deliver his New Year remarks... which will no doubt provide us with a better idea of what to expect from him and his administration in the coming year.

We''re looking at some major political changes to start off with... a new prime minister... a Cabinet reshuffle... a possible ruling-opposition summit... and the launch of a new ruling party...
And this is just to name a few... that are expected within the first weeks of next month.
All the while... economic recovery and reform efforts will have to go on...
Seoul will have to keep trying to better its relations with the world... especially the communist North Korea...
And as President Kim''s been saying over the past few weeks... the government faces the task of improving the quality of life for the people of Korea... particularly those in the low-income bracket who have suffered the most from the country''s economic crisis.
And all of these things will likely be reflected in President Kim''s New Year address... which 

of course, we, at Arirang TV... will be sure to bring (that) to you as it happens.
In the meantime... that''s all for this special live coverage of President Kim''s year-end remarks.
I''m Ahn Junghyun... coming to you from Seoul.
Thanks for watching... and take care.?

? Seoul has requested Beijing allow Korean firms to take part in China''s first-phase code division multiple access or CDMA projects... and its car market.
? Finance and Economy Minister Kang Bong-kyun made the formal request to his Chinese counterpart in Beijing yesterday.
Kang also asked for the Chinese government''s support in completing Daewoo''s auto plant in that country... as well as other projects involving nuclear plants, high-speed rail construction, and the production of mid-sized aircrafts.
The Chinese government in turn promised to encourage related state agencies and companies to cooperate with this request.?
artcl_titl: Korea Asks China to Open Auto Mart
artcl_titl_en: Korea Asks China to Open Auto Mart

artcl_ctt:
? Hope your Tuesday is going well...
Here are the headlines at this hour...

? 37 firms under court protection are being forced to shut down.

? And... for the internet savvy... phone bills could be coming down, with the turn of the year.

? Meantime... European countries are picking up the pieces from last week''s deadly downpours.?

? Going to the local markets now... which are preparing to wrap up the year this afternoon...
First, the stock market... 
The KOSPI this morning... is riding on yesterday''s momentum and climbing even higher... to near 1-thosuand 30.
But... on the f-x trading floor... 
the won is trading rather flat at 11-35 per U-S dollar.

Those are the stories at this hour...
We hope you''ll stay with Arirang TV for all the latest stories...
Thank you for watching!?

? More than 80-percent of Korean lawyers say... ? they support changing or downright getting rid of the National Security Law.
This... according to a recent survey by the Korean Bar Association.
950 attorneys took part... and 58-percent backed revising the law... while 24-percent pushed for its abolishment.
Almost 60-percent said the National Security Law has been abused politically... and thereby negatively affecting the society.?

? Singapore''s manufacturing output rose 18-percent last month compared to the same period last year.
This, backed by strong demand for electronics and chemicals products... which form the twin pillars that fuel the Singaporean economy.
? The country''s Economic Development Board says electronics production in November rose 25-and-a-half percent... with strong gains in the telecommunications equipment and semiconductor industries.
Production of personal computers and printers also rose from a year ago... but output of disk drives remained slow due to corporate restructuring.
Pharmaceuticals production also grew a robust 63 percent... with inceased exports of high value-added chemicals to the European Union.?

?A final privatization plan is expected soon... for Korea Heavy Industries and Construction.
And for now... it looks like big business won''t be in the picture.

? Domestic conglomerates will likely be excluded from the government''s plan to privatize Hanjung... or Korea Heavy Industries and Construction.
This is a change from Seoul''s initial plan to hold an international tender... and is expected to spark strong opposition from interested business groups.
Related government ministries including the Finance and Economy and Planning and Budget... will soon meet to seal Hanjung''s fate.
Reports say it has tentatively decided to allot 20 to 25 percent of Hanjung shares to US firm General Electric and German firm ABB-Combustion Engineering.
A portion of the state-run firm''s equities will also go to Hanjung''s Employee Stock Ownership Association.
The government''s privitization plan also includes listing Hanjung''s shares on the local bourse after April''s general elections.
Meanwhile... the labor union and management at Hanjung reached an agreement on Monday to end a 48-day strike and to set up a joint countermeasure committee to discuss the privitization plan.?

? A much talked about political summit... between the heads of rival camps... has yet to materialize.
But things moved in that direction... with the following remarks by the opposition leader.

? To give people hope in the nation''s politics, in time for the new millennium.
This is the reason opposition leader Lee Hoi-chang says he''s willing to meet early next week... President Kim... the head of the ruling National Congress for New Politics.
While welcoming Lee''s proposal to meet... the President''s spokesman... pointed out preparatory talks are needed to set the agenda for the Kim-Lee summit.
Spokesman Park Joon-young expressed reservations about Lee''s proposal that President Kim step down from the N-C-N-P top post... which the opposition leader insists is key to ensuring fair competition in next April''s general elections.
Also on the G-N-P leader''s agenda... independence for the prosecution and the National Intelligence Service... as well as improving inter-party relations.
Chongawade meantime, has its own agenda drawn up...
Since the ruling party proposed the Kim-Lee talks late last month... the presidential house has been working on a joint statement... pledging productive politics, fair competition in April''s elections and uprooting regional antagonism.
Although the date has yet to be set... inside sources say there''s a good chance the Kim-Lee summit will be held next week.?

?Welcome to Arirang News.
I''m (    ) in Seoul.

The government has ordered 37 companies... under court mediation or receivership... to shut down.
?This is after creditor banks... along with the Financial Supervisory Service... deemed these firms non-viable.
Facing liquidation... the 37 companies account for almost half of all businesses under court mediation or receivership.
The F-S-S also plans to take similar action for troubled firms... that are currently under creditor-led debt rescheduling programs... or the so-called "workouts."
Lender banks say another nine companies could be forced to closed down... during next year''s first half.?

? Despite liquidity troubles in the corporate sector... facility investments are on the rise.
?The Korea Stock Exchange says... as of last Saturday... listed firms had invested 8-point-6 trillion won... or roughly 7-billion US dollars... in 66 cases.
That''s a 10-percent rise from the total... for all of last year.
Analysts say... the rise is actually greater... as companies are making fresh investments... and expanding facilities.
Taking this into account... a listed company''s average facility investment amounts to more than 162-billion won so far... a year-on-year  jump of 75-percent..?

? And with that we turn now to the stories in the local dailies...

? Starting next year... competition among telecom companies is expected to bring down international phone rates.
Some will even be for free.
Here''s how it works... consumers can make a free call by logging into a designated website... then the sponsors of ads on the site... pay for the call.

And to ring in the year two thousand... 
Two thousand dancers will perform at the site of the new international airport near Inchon... just west of Seoul.

Big businesses are preparing changes in time for the new millennium... 
They''ve picked seven key goals of management.
Businesses will reportedly concentrate on improving... information and technology... ethics... cash flow... specialization... venture linkups... strategic alliances... and the endless pursuit of becoming number one.

And here''s an encouraging story of someone who has beaten extraordinary odds...
A visually impaired pianist has been accepted to Sookmyung University.
Kim Yaeji(김예지) lost her eyesight when she was two years old.
Despite her physical challenges... Kim memorized musical sheets by heart and has practiced playing the piano for the past ten years.
She says whenever she''s playing her piano... she can conjure up memories of when she was little... riding on her sled or looking at the flowers in her garden.

And now... OUR top story for this morning.?

Front page for 12/28:

1.  무료 전화 시대
2.  영종도 새천년 행사 (사진)
3.  새 경영 지침서
4.  시각 장애인 숙대 입학

? This year''s Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to Doctors Without Borders.... medical volunteers who often risk their lives in some of the world''s most dangerous hot spots.
The group... like so many NGO''s ... focuses on humanitarian rather than commercial objectives.
?In the easiest terms... N-G-Os are non-profit, voluntary groups that work for the welfare of the community... from small grass roots projects... to those that cover global issues... like banning landmines, protecting the environment, or the struggle for human rights.?
NGOs are concerned citizens with a common goal... to create a civil society.
?"NGOs are vital to the work in human rights because they''re at the grass roots.
They work with people, they work with vulnerable communities, with those who are marginalized, with prisoners, with those who have suffered disappearances of family members."?
At the Seoul Conference... there were as many topics for discussion as there are problems in the world.
How to achieve gender equality, how to insure the quality of life for the elderly... how to provide children with education and health benefits.
On the grounds of Olympic Park, delegates shared not only their successes and failures but also strategies on how to make their missions more productive.
?"Networking is probably what makes these conferences effective.
At the conferences, you hear many things and  your mind is open to new ideas but the networking makes it become effective for people.
Otherwise, it''s just talk and talk is no good."? 
As for the host country, the conference acted as a wakeup call for local NGOs.
Ordinary citizens have also become more aware of the civic groups... several schools have even adopted NGO classes in their curriculum.
?	 00;06;00;00 "Korean NGOs may have a shorter history compared to other groups abroad but we are able to exert a great amount of influence in society.
On one hand, Korea has undergone remarkable growth but on the other, there are still many underdeveloped factors in our country.
That''s why civil movements in Korea have great potential and power."?

Already, many watchdog groups are gearing up to monitor next year''s general elections.
According to Jeong, other prominent concerns in the Korean NGO community will be women''s issues and human rights, especially the welfare of North Korean defectors.
Oh JiWon Arirang TV.?

? Russian forces are firing non-stop at the Chechen capital... hoping to move further into the city.
? Russia''s attack is led by pro-Moscow soldiers of Grozny... who know the city well.
But... the federal troops aren''t finding it easy to advance into the capital... faced with stiff resistance from Chechen rebels.
According to the Interfax News Agency... Chechen fighters have found Russian forces'' weak spots... and have regrouped accordingly.
From Moscow however... Prime Minister Vladimir Putin says the attack on Grozny is going as planned.?
artcl_titl: 러 공군, 체첸 남부 폭탄 투하#Russia bombs Grozny non-stop#
artcl_titl_en: 러 공군, 체첸 남부 폭탄 투하#Russia bombs Grozny non-stop#

artcl_ctt:
?Over in Europe... the death toll from last week''s storms rises to 79.
?More than half the victims were in France... where one-and-a-half-million people are still without electricity.
The Paris government says... it''ll take at least three years... and billions of dollars... to restore damage to the city.
Meanwhile... three Korean mountaineers... who''d been stranded in the French Alps since Sunday... had to be rescued by helicopter.
Killer storms had roared through the region over the weekend.?

?Prosecutors today will summon Kumho Group chairman Park Jung-koo (박정구)... amid allegations of stock price-rigging.
?Overnight... authorities questioned his brother Park Sam-gu (박삼구)... who heads Asiana Airlines.
Still unclear... is whether or not Park and his brothers... had used inside information... to make illegal profits.
The family... allegedly sold shares in Kumho Tires to the group''s petrochemical unit last April... before their merger... and earned 920-million won.
Prosecutors have also cross-examined the Asiana president''s testimony... against statements by Park Chan-koo(박찬구)... head of the petrochemical divison.
Both men deny the charges... saying they were only trying to defend their management rights.?

? Over in England... protesters are demonstrating against the killing of another kind.
This time it''s the old British tradition... of fox hunting.
We get a closer look in this report.

?It''s the day after Christmas and one of the largest fox hunts is about to take place in the southern country of Essex.
Riders were met with greeted by enthusiastic fans.
?"Look at the genunine Maldon people they''re cheerful, they''re happy, they''re pleased to see us."
But along with the cheers there were also jeers.

Protests at fox hunts have become alot as much as a  tradition as the hunt themselves.
?"Count the horses, count the dogs, count the people and they''re after one little fellow like this. You know it''s just disgusting."

Despite the strong tradition of the hunt.. it just might become unrooted.
Protestors are gaining ground as the British government recently announced an independent inquirey into hunting.... for there is growing number of lawmakers who support the ban... and makes fox hunting an endangered sport.?

?And finally.
With the economy on the rebound... bank loans to small businesses have risen sharply... exceeding 100-trillion won... or 83-billion dollars.
?The Bank of Korea says... loans to these businesses jumped almost 20-trillion won... this year... from just a year ago.
Analysts say better economic conditions are stimulating more business activity... and companies are looking for more capital to expand.
Plus... banks are lending more money to small companies with growth potential these days... compared to two years ago... during the height of Korea''s financial crisis.

That''s the latest.
Have a good day.?

? The tiny island of Kiribati located on the equator in the central Pacific Ocean... will be the first nation to greet the year 2000.
And it''s planning to celebrate the new millennium... island-style.
We get a sneak preview in this report.

? Plans are under way to televise the first celebrations in the new millennium.
It''s proximity to the international time line, makes Kiribati''s Millennium island the first place on Earth to ring in the new millennium.
Midnight here is 14 hours ahead of London and 19 hours ahead of New York.
A television crew along with 70 Kiribati dancers journeyed to Millennium Island by boat... where the crew had to dig wells for drinking water and cut down thick vegetation to form a campsite.
The survival skills of the islanders helped the crew to manage ... nature supplying most of the nourishment they need.
Nature also takes care of the costumes for the celebration... the islanders are planning to perform traditional dances.
? "The dancers have been on the road themselves since the end of November, that''s nearly a month''s travelling to get here, they are really committed to this project and they have had to overcome seasickness, home sickness to come to this remote place to do their thing for the world."
The Kiribati islanders have been staging final rehearsals for traditional midnight and dawn ceremonies.
The island is isolated from the modern world, but everyone participating in the event, senses its historic significance.
All indications are that a beautiful performance will accompany the dawning of a new era.?
(Title)
(Ending Title)

? 37 companies under court mediation or receivership have been ordered to shut down by the government.
? The call came after creditors, along with the Financial Supervisory Service... decided the firms were non-viable.
Soon to be liquidated... the 37 companies... account for almost half of all businesses under court mediation or receivership.
The FSS also plans to take similar measures for troubled companies... currently subject to creditor-led debt rescheduling... or the workout programs.
Creditor banks predict another nine firms could be forced to close down... during the first half of next year.?

? The Justice Ministry plans to expand legal benefits next year... to cover a greater number of citizens.
? For one... workers with monthly wages of under one and a half million won... will be able to take advantage of free public legal services.
Currently... the services are limited to those with incomes of under 1-point-3 million won a month.
And they''ll also cover a greater variety of cases... not just civil suits.
In addition... plans have been drawn up... to deal with complaints about defense provided by state-appointed lawyers.?

? Most Asian bourses were relatively quiet this Tuesday...

But the Tokyo market posted a strong performance... the Nikkei 225 rising 236 points... to close at 18-thousand-783.
This, as Japanese technology stocks rallied... in the wake of a two-for-one share split by Sony Corporation.?

? Hong Kong''s Hang Seng index added on 95 points or half a percent... to end the day at 16-thousand-928.
Traders say follow-through buying of technology-related stocks and market laggards... outweighed profit-taking.

Meanwhile... Kuala Lumpur''s Composite Index rose one-and-a-half percent to 797 points.

And down in Singapore, blue-chip selling pulled back the Straits Times index...
The market closed 13 points or half a percent lower... at just under 24-47.

The Sydney market remained closed for a public holiday.

And now let''s check out the day''s exchange rates.?

? Opposition leader Lee Hoi-chang has proposed a summit talks with President Kim Dae-jung early next year.
? At a press conference this morning....Lee said he will meet with the President without ANY preconditions.....to give hope to the people and offer a fresh vision on the state affairs for the new millennium.
The Grand National Party president added that the one-on-one talks should focus on mapping out big structure for the politics....and leave pending issues such as revising election law to separate meetings between senior ruling and opposition camp officials.
During the summit.....Lee said..... he would ask President Kim to leave his ruling party to remain neural in next April''s general elections.?

? A local venture firm has developed a software program that allows internet users to surf the world wide web in their own language and font.
Joy-Seven says its conversion program has 197 languages from Spanish... to Russian.... which can be applied to all web-browsers like Explorer and Netscape.
Until now, English has been regarded as the universal language of the Internet.... oftentimes, it''s the only language in which data is conveyed.
But Joy-Seven says ... with their product, all it takes is one click of the mouse to convert language and fonts.
The price of the program... is 35 US dollars.?

? There''s hardly any progress in talks between Indian negotiators and hijackers of an Indian Airlines plane... with a hundred fifty-five people still on board.
? Officials in Afganistan... where the plane has been since Saturday... said the two sides continued discussions into the early hours of Tuesday... but failed to reach a compromise.
The hijackers are still demanding the release of a Muslim activist... prisoned in India.
They''ve threatened to start killing passengers... if their demands went unheeded.
So far... one person''s been stabbed to death.
Indian officials have since resumed negotiations with the hijackers... but all the while... conditions on the hijacked plane... are said to be fast detriorating.?

World oil prices surpass $26 per barrel, after Iran''s oil minister says the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will likely curb supply for another six months after next March.

? The long drawn-out strike at Korea Heavy Industries... is over.
The union and management... hammered out a seven-point agreement... covering issues such as the company''s privatization plans... and unpaid wages.
We learn more in this report.

? The union and management of the state-run Korea Heavy Industries and Construction or Hanjung... finally reached an agreement... ending a 48-day strike.
Company president Yoon Young-suk(윤영석) and Union chair Sohn Seok-hyung(손석형) struck a seven-point compromise... on the company''s privatization plan and wages.
According to the agreement... all of the current workers will be retained... even after the company is privatized.
Also, the state-run company will donate one billion won... or about 890-thousand U-S dollars... for unionists to buy company stocks... in addition to arranging favorable interest rates on bank loans for stock purchases.
Meanwhile, each worker will be able to receive six-month, interest-free loans from the company... worth up to one million won.
And unionists who suffered pay cuts during the strike... will be given a bonus... if the company manages to recover strike-related losses... within the next six months.
Observers say... normal operations at the state-run firm are expected to resume on Wednesday morning.?
artcl_titl: 한국중공업 노사협상 타결#Korea Heavy Ind. Strike Ends in Compromise#
artcl_titl_en: 한국중공업 노사협상 타결#Korea Heavy Ind. Strike Ends in Compromise#

? For the first time this year... flower exports recorded a trade surplus... and is expected to hit ?18-million US dollars by the end of the year.
The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry says this is about six-million dollars more than last year... when exports totalled 12-million dollars.
Officials attribute the rise to an effort by domestic flower growers to come up with diverse breeds as well as the popularity of the products among European and Japanese consumers.
On the other hand... flower imports have dwindled in the last few years... to post 15-point-6 million dollars this year.?
artcl_titl: Flower Exports Expected to Hit $18-Mil This Year
artcl_titl_en: Flower Exports Expected to Hit $18-Mil This Year

artcl_ctt:
? Koreans puffed away 5-trillion won worth of cigarettes and other tabacco products last year...up 0-point-7 percent from the previous year.
? As for foreign brand cigarettes, their consumption dropped year to year by 55 percent with total sales worth 389-billion won.
National Statistical Office said on a year to year comparison...consumption of alcoholic beverages except for soju decreased last year...with every Korean adult drinking 3-point-4 bottles more Soju than in the previous year....when the financial crisis became full-blown.
N-S-O also added that with deep economic crisis...people on state welfare amounted to 180-thousand last year...about 12 times more than the previous year.?
artcl_titl: Koreans Smoked Away $5 tril Last Year
artcl_titl_en: Koreans Smoked Away $5 tril Last Year

artcl_ctt:
? Amid last year''s economic difficulties... Koreans had to cut down on expensive whiskey, foreign cigarettes, and overseas travel.
But... much has changed this year... with the economy bouncing back.
Here''s a closer look at the findings by the National Statistical Office.

? The 19-99 Korea Social Indices report shows the nation''s economic rebound has led to a surge in spending for most things.
From January to September this year... the amount of whiskey taken out of warehouses and delivered to stores and restaurants... almost tripled ... to near 12-thousand-five-hundred kiloliters.
Delivery of the traditional Korean liquor soju rose a mere eight percent ... to 688-thousand kiloliters.
It''s a sharp contrast from last year... when only soju managed to enjoy any increase in sales.
Koreans this year are also smoking more expensive foreign cigarettes.
After plummeting 50 percent last year... sales of foreign brands during this year''s first eleven months, grew nearly 20 percent.
Koreans are using more energy, electricity consumption has shot up 10 percent from last year... to 158-thousand giga-watts.
Households were responsible for a 65 percent hike in power use.
The number of mobile phone subscribers meanwhile keeps going up, 22 million at the end of October... that means one out of every two people... own a handphone.
And there''s a new boom in overseas travel... 3-point-9 million people had gone abroad by November... more than last year''s total.?
artcl_titl: 양주 출고량 3 배 등 # 99 Korean Social Indices #
artcl_titl_en: 양주 출고량 3 배 등 # 99 Korean Social Indices #

artcl_ctt:
ECONOMIC OUTLOOK 2000

The Bank of Korea predicts 7% GDP growth rate for next year, with similarly healthy figures for the trade surplus, consumption, and facility investment.
-------------------------------
DINNER WITH THE PRESIDENTS

President Kim, during dinner with three, former presidents, talks about what his national and foreign policies accomplished in 1999, and his goals for next year.
-------------------------------
BREAKING A THOUSAND

Korea''s benchmark stock index, a day before wrapping up a banner year, rises for the fourth consecutive session to regain the 1,000 point level.
-------------------------------
STRIKE ENDING DEAL

Union and management of the state-run Korea Heavy Industries & Construction Co. reach a seven-point compromise, ending a strike that had lasted 48 days.

?The central bank has a rosy outlook for next year''s GDP growth... trade surplus... and consumption.

?President Kim... during a meeting tonight with three... former leaders... talks about the accomplishments and goals of his national and foreign policies.

?And stock prices... a day before wrapping up a banner year... rise for the fourth... consecutive session of trading.?

?Welcome to Arirang News.
I''m Ahn Junghyun in Seoul.
?And I''m Hyun Chulho.
This is your final edition for December 27th.?

? Well... the likelihood President Kim would meet opposition leader ?? Lee Hoi-chang any time soon... has faded... with inter-party negotiations on political reform and other issues still pending.
Lee... who heads the Grand National Party... says he''s not heard anything about such a summit... from the Presidential Office or the ruling party.
The ruling National Congress for New Politics and the G-N-P have reportedly been mulling over a private meeting between Lee and the President... for a fresh start to the new year.
But inter-party tensions have yet to subside... especially with negotiations to redraw voting districts for next April''s general election... being suspended.?

? And a colorful performance graced a stage in northern Seoul last night.
? Ichita Yamamoto... a Japanese lawmaker... whose expertise is in foreign affairs... performed live songs he wrote and composed.
These works were to promote friendlier ties between Seoul and Tokyo... ahead of the 2002 World Cup soccer finals... which the two countries will cohost.
The concert last night... will be the first in a series of performances... to be held in both Seoul and Tokyo... with the spotlight on senior government officials from both.
For instance... next April... in Japan... Korean ruling party lawmaker Kim Sang-woo is planning to sing a repertoire of jazz standards.?

? Hello and welcome to Newsroom Update.

? President Kim Dae-jung will be hosting a dinner party tonight for his predecessors.
Former presidents Choi Kyu-hah, Chun Doo-hwan, and Roh Tae-woo... as well as the Prime Minister, Chief Justice, and National Assembly Speaker will be at the gathering.
The Presidential Office says though that ex-president Kim Young-sam will not be attending... due to personal reasons.
President Kim is expected to talk about the government''s economic recovery efforts and his diplomatic achievements this year.
He also plans to hear the former Chief Executives'' opinions on next year''s state agenda.

? The owners of the Kumho Group are under investigation for manipulating share prices.
Prosecutors questioned the head of Kumho Petrochemical, Park Chan-koo (박찬구) overnight.
He allegedly bought nearly five-million shares in Kumho Tire... before the official announcement of the company''s merger with the Group''s construction unit.
Park, along with his brothers, is also accused of embezzling profits... by tampering with the price of shares in the tire company last April.
Prosecutors also plan to summon the Kumho Group chairman and the president of Asiana Airlines.

? In western Europe... more than 50 people are dead and hundreds injured in the wake of heavy downpours and gusty winds over the Christmas holiday.
At least half of the victims were killed... by falling trees.
France suffered the most... with gales of almost 100 miles per hour... flattening thousands of houses.
Air, rail and road traffic were either suspended or delayed by the devastating weather.
Reports say more than 100 people... mostly homeless... were killed this winter, due to the freezing conditions.

That is all for now.
Thanks for watching.?

Hello. Welcome to Hotel Navigation.
I''m Shim Miryung.
With the countdown to the new millennium just a few days away, hotels are busier than ever testing their computers for the Y2K bug.

Both millennium packages offer much in the way of fun and entertaiment...  from techno dancing and fashion shows to fireworks.
Or if winning prizes is more to your liking ... you can try your luck with the hotel lottery.
Not a bad way to spend the evening on the eve to the new millenium... gliding on ice at Korea''s only outdoor hotel skating rink.... or enjoying hot cocoa and snacks on the ringside.

? Meanwhile... Prime Minister Kim is expected to return to his United Liberal Democrats party... around ? the 10th of next month.
A senior U-L-D official also quotes Kim as saying... after his return... he would try to recruit conservative figures from all sectors of society.
Park Tae-joon, who''s currently the party leader... is a likely candidate to replace the prime minister.
Although he has yet to be offered the position... Park recently told reporters... he has considered the likelihood.?

artcl_ctt:
? 200-thousand more Koreans will be eligible for disability benefits... starting next year.
The expansion follows the government''s revising the legal definition of "disability".
Here''s more on the changes.

? New law enforcement regulations will provide greater benefits to more handicapped people.
The Health and Welfare Ministry says until now, those with mental disorders and disabilities involving the five senses such as sight and hearing have been categorized as handicapped.
But starting from this Saturday January first, ?the relevant laws will be changed to include people suffering from all mental diseases, autism, chronic kidney and heart disorders.
Also people who are blind in only one eye, men who stand at less than 145 centimeters and women at less than 140 centimeters? will receive benefits.
The expanded criteria is forecast to include some 230 thousand new people on the list of 634 thousand currently registered nationwide as disabled.
Meanwhile the benefits are currently comprised of government subsidies, ?discounts on public facilities, and help in finding jobs.
Changes include making the use of sign language mandatory in events marking national holidays and state-organized speeches.?
The Ministry advises those subject to the new guidelines to report to their local district offices to receive benefits.?
artcl_titl: Category to be expanded for Disabled#Disabled Category#
artcl_titl_en: Category to be expanded for Disabled#Disabled Category#

artcl_ctt:
?Along similiar lines.
A pan-national hand-holding movement is being ?pushed by the Korean National Council of Churches, the Chogye Buddhist sect... and other religious groups in Korea.
Today the KNCC held a meeting for senior journalists... to explain the event... scheduled to start on the first of this coming March.
It''s being billed as a show of unity.
The KNCC''s General Secretary Kim Dong-wan(김동완) says the movement will be about overcoming ideological differences... and showing the people''s will for inter-Korean reconciliation.
The KNCC says work is underway with North Korea... to have citizens link hands... all the way from the North''s Shinuiju(신의주) and Pyongyang... to the South''s Seoul and cities in the provinces.?

? Seoul hosted an international conference of NGO''s or nongovernmental organizations this fall.
Recognizing the growing importance of NGO''s worldwide... Seoul played host to an international conference of NGO''s this October.
2000 groups from 100? countries took part in what was the first ever multi-issue NGO gathering... covering everything from gender equality... to sustainable economic growth.
Here''s Arirang''s Oh JiWon on the growing prominence of NGO''s...

? This year''s Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to a group of medical volunteers... known in English as Doctors Without Borders.
They were praised by the Nobel committee for working under difficult circumstances... often putting their lives at risk... in some of the world''s most dangerous hot spots. 
Doctors Without Borders... like so many nongovernmental organizations or N-G-O''s... focuses on humanitarian rather than profit oriented goals.
N-G-Os are non-profit, voluntary groups that work to benefit the welfare of the community... from small grass roots projects... to those that cover global issues... like banning landmines, protecting the environment, and fighting for human rights.
?"NGOs are vital to the work in human rights because they''re at the grass roots.
They work with people, they work with vulnerable communities, with those who are marginalized, with prisoners, with those who have suffered disappearances of family members."?
NGOs are concerned citizens with a common goal... to create a civil society.
And with much to do, NGO participants were busy with numerous plenary and group sessions, clinics, cultural events and informal meetings... all aimed at alliance building among NGO''s.

There are as many topics for discussion as there are problems in the world.
How to achieve gender equality, how to insure the quality of life for the elderly... how to provide children with education and health benefits.

In large conference halls or tents on the grounds of Olympic Park, delegates shared not only their successes and failures but also strategies on how to make their missions more productive.

They tackled issues ranging from gender equality... to eradicating poverty... to the rights of the elderly.
Ideas were exchanged... contacts made... petitions signed... ultimately to help drive NGOs to action.
?"Networking is probably what makes these conferences effective.
At the conferences, you hear many things and  your mind is open to new ideas but the networking makes it become effective for people.
Otherwise, it''s just talk and talk is no good."?






Oh JiWon Arirang TV.?

? On this year''s second last trading day... ? Korean stocks shot up one and-a-half percent... to break through the one-thousand barrier again.
? Led by a rally in telecom stocks... the benchmark KOSPI rose 14 points... to a thousand-five and three-quarters.?
This is raising expectations... the market will end 19-99 safely above the thousand mark.
Trading volume totalled 232 million shares... on turnover of 4-trillion won.
Despite the general rise... losing issues outnumbered winners 5 to 3.
? Little action, meanwhile... on the forex market... the Korean currency weakening by about 2 won... to close at a touch under 11-34 for every US dollar.?

artcl_ctt:
? At Chongwadae... President Kim Dae-jung hosted a dinner last night... for his predecessors and top figures from the legislative, judicial and administrative branches.
? Ex-presidents Choi Kyu-ha, Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Taewoo came with their wives... as did Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil, Chief Justice Choi Jong-young and National Assembly Speaker Park Jun-kyu.
But former president Kim Young-sam turned down the invitation... citing personal reasons.
Chongwadae sources say the dinner lasted for about an hour and a half... in a friendly atmosphere.
President Kim explained Korea''s economic recovery process... and asked the others to play a constructive role in rooting out regional antagonism.
Chun and Roh, in return... praised the economy''s quick turnaround... and promised to do what they can to achieve national unity.
The former leaders also called on the Kim Administration to pursue future-oriented policies in the coming century.?
artcl_titl: Chongwadae dinner #DJ hosts dinner for predecessors#
artcl_titl_en: Chongwadae dinner #DJ hosts dinner for predecessors#

artcl_ctt:
? The country''s largest automaker, Hyundai Motor, is against a foreign firm assuming a controlling stake in Daewoo''s car unit.
Analysts say this comes amid concerns the company may loose its dominant share in the ? domestic market... once a foreign carmaker takes over.
But auto industry watchers are opposing suggestions to nationalize Daewoo Motor... due to the enormous amount of debt the automaker has chalked up over the years... amounting to 18-trillion won.
As for the possibility of Hyundai assuming control over the ailing unit... experts believe creating a monopoly would stifle competition and lead to an overall weakening of the industry.
Hyundai as well as General Motors of the US have already made their interests in Daewoo Motor clear... while Ford is expected to submit its tender soon.?
artcl_titl: Hyundai Opposes Foreign Takeover of Daewoo Motor
artcl_titl_en: Hyundai Opposes Foreign Takeover of Daewoo Motor

artcl_ctt:
? When you look at the figures... Asian economies are on the rebound.
But then... there ARE aspects of life... that''ll take longer to return to where they were... before the crisis.
Arirang Oh Jiwon covered an international conference in Korea... on something more personal than the numbers... the impact on the family.

? Just two years ago, once-thriving Asian economies took a nosedive.
Companies went bankrupt, regional currencies took a tumble... while hundreds of thousands of workers lost their jobs. 
Suddenly, many were without means to support themselves or their families.
? "So many more people have become poorer.
Those who were starting to just get a little bit of a breather were being pulled back again.
Only slowly are some of them been able to get out of it, but it''s going to be a long process."
And caught up in the economic quagmire are the children.
Developing Asian economies are reporting a growing number of kids who are suffering from malnutrition.
That''s alarming... in that a whole generation of children may be impaired in their physical and intellectual development.
? "Although signs of a gradual economic recovery are evident throughout the region, experts say the social repercussions from the crisis will take much longer to reverse."
Poverty is on the rise... while middle class living standards are on a sharp decline.
?"There has been a serious degree of family breakups in Korea.
There have been many instances of parents leaving their children, and couples divorcing or living separately under forced circumstances."
Participants are calling for stronger social safety nets, more job opportunities, and education assistance for children of low-income families.
According to the panelists, the financial crisis has brought on hardships to many people in Asia... but the crisis has also brought to the forefront, the importance of families as a fundamental social unit... that serves as the  backbone to a nation''s welfare and development.
Oh JiWon Arirang TV for CNN World Report.?
artcl_titl: CNN: Impact of Asian Financial Crisis on Families
artcl_titl_en: CNN: Impact of Asian Financial Crisis on Families

artcl_ctt:
? While there are definite signs of a recovering economy... the truth is... there are also people struggling to make ends meet in Korea.
Well... reporter Oh JiWon has the story about a community service program... that''s making a difference this holiday season.
And it''s about sharing one of life''s most basic needs.

? The Food Bank system operates on a simple principle... reduce hunger by reducing waste.
Businesses donate excess fruits, vegetables, canned goods and other food stuff to local food bank chapters.
Volunteers either pick up the food or connect the donor with families or organizations in need.
? "There are many needy people ever since the IMF crisis.
We are glad to give what little we can to help the homeless, the elderly and orphanges."?
The food bank accepts slightly damaged grocery goods... like dented cans... items that won''t sell but are still too good to throw away.
Most of the time, donations are surplus products that retailers would have returned to their suppliers.
?"This is keeping good food from going to waste.
It also clears unwanted merchandise from store shelves and reduces disposal costs.
In all, it''s a win-win situation for everyone involved."?
Contributions are tax deductible and needless to say, the food is appreciated by many in the community.
The food bank network enables organizations to stretch their limited resources.
?"The donations really help the mothers.
The condiments go a long way in preparing side dishes."
That means other necessities like clothing and medicine can be purchased with the grocery money that is saved.
?  "This is more than simply giving handouts.
Those on the receiving end know there are people who care.
And that fosters a sense of unity."?	
According to Mr. Choi, who oversees the food bank program in Seoul, requests for emergency food are higher than ever but donations, unfortunately, lag behind.
So on a day like this, volunteers from day care centers, nursing homes, and half-way houses are more than happy to load heavy boxes of donated goods.
They all agree it''s the spirit of sharing that helps them through the tough times.
Oh JiWon Arirang TV for CNN World Report.?

? Financial experts say... the government should reduce the amount of currency stabilization bonds... that are issued to control the money supply.
They''re warning... an excess of these bonds could trigger inflation.

? The value of outstanding currency stabilization bonds has been on the rise... over the past two years.
If the trend continues... such bonds could amount to 80-trillion won, or 65-billion U-S dollars... towards the end of next year.
That is according to a recent study by the Korea Institute of Finance.
Researchers there warn that an excess supply of currency stabilization bonds... could exert inflationary pressure.
These bonds totaled around 20-trillion won until 19-97...
But, the government started issuing more of these bonds in 19-98... to cope with the financial restructuring projects.
As of the end of June outstanding bonds stood at 52-trillion won.
Increased amount of bonds translates to a rise in the interest burden.
An increase in interest payments... would further expand money supply... which would, in turn, exert greater inflationary pressure.
As a solution... the K-I-F suggests that authorities reduce the amount of outstanding currency stabilization bonds.
The institute also recommends converting them to government bonds... since currency stabilization bonds, unlike the latter... does hot help in promoting the bond market.?
artcl_titl: 내년 통안증권 잔액 80조원#Currency stabilization bonds may reach 80 tril#
artcl_titl_en: 내년 통안증권 잔액 80조원#Currency stabilization bonds may reach 80 tril#

artcl_titl_en: 이 총재, "총재 회담 응할 생각 없어"
