? The Korea Stock Exchange wraps up a banner year of trading tomorrow.
? After opening in January at under 590... the benchmark KOSPI soared to cap last week at 992.
That''s a leap of almost 70 percent for the year.
And today... it regained the one-thousand mark.
The boom is largely attributed to renewed interest in local stocks... especially among foreign investors.
Tomorrow''s closing ceremony at the KSE will be highlighted by the customary throwing of colored paper as confetti.?
artcl_titl: 증시 내일 폐장# KSE Closes for Year Tomorrow #
artcl_titl_en: 증시 내일 폐장# KSE Closes for Year Tomorrow #

artcl_titl: 여객시 납치범, 승객 살해 최후 통첩
artcl_titl_en: 여객시 납치범, 승객 살해 최후 통첩

artcl_ctt:
? Going to Chechnya now... 
Russian forces over the weekend... bombed their way further into the capital of Grozny.
Although many say the federal troops are making little progress... some of Moscow''s troop commanders claim... the operation will soon be over.
Here''s the situation.

?Russian tanks and cannons fired wave after wave of shells into Grozny while  special forces and pro-Moscow Chechen fighters entered the city. 
Shell explosions and the rattle of large caliber guns were heard throughout the city where 40-thousand civilians remained trapped.
Moscow officials are vowing not to storm the city...perhaps  to avoid the mistakes of the Chechen war in the mid 90''s in which ill trained Russian infantry stormed the city only to be surrounded and mauled by rebels. ''
Sources say Russian troops have crossed Minutka square which is just a short drive from the heart of Grozny.
Meanwhile...rebels have been using hit and run tactics during the dark and planting booby traps on major supply roads.
However.. according to Russian media... officers say Russia will have full control of Grozny in the near future.?

? Hope you enjoyed your holiday weekend.
Good Morning.
Today is Monday, December twenty-seventh, 19-99.
Many parts of Korea are starting this final week of the year under a blanket of thick fogs.
They''ll give way to clouds by the afternoon.?

? 400 Korean soldiers will be ringing in the new year... miles away from home.
? They are the members of the Evergreen Unit... stationed in East Timor since October... as part of an international peacekeeping force.
With improvements in the security situation... the soldiers say they''re now working to forge closer ties and work with the locals.
The Evergreen Force is the first Korean combat unit to be sent abroad... since the 19-60s Vietnam War.?
artcl_titl: 동티모르 비바 코리아#Evergreen Unit: working with the locals#
artcl_titl_en: 동티모르 비바 코리아#Evergreen Unit: working with the locals#

artcl_ctt:
? That is our report at this hour.
We thank you for starting your week with us... and hope to see you back here soon.?

? Reconstruction is underway in western Europe... where mother nature crushed this year''s holiday spirits.
? Heavy downpours and gusty winds over the weekend... left more than fifty people dead.
At least half of the victims were killed... by falling trees.
Hundreds are reported injured as well.
France was the hardest hit... with gales of almost 100 miles per hour... flattening thousands of houses.
Air, rail and road traffic were either suspended or delayed.
Meanwhile in Russia... five people died on Sunday from frostbite... while more than fifty have been checked into hospitals.
Itar-Tass News Agency reports... the death toll from hypothermia in Moscow this winter... rose to 105.?
artcl_titl: 서유럽 살인 폭풍#Killer weather in Europe#
artcl_titl_en: 서유럽 살인 폭풍#Killer weather in Europe#

artcl_ctt:
? Now to a rosy outlook for the Korean economy.
The Bank of Korea predicts... among other figures... a GDP growth rate of seven percent... next year.
Here''s a closer look at the projections.

? It won''t be this year''s double digit growth... but the central bank expects Korea to grow another seven percent in the coming year.
The Bank of Korea says... ? exports will continue to rise in the new year... helping Korea to enjoy another trade surplus... although... it will be half of this year''s at 11-point-5 billion dollars.?
Based on customs calculations... Korea will be in the black by 16 billion dollars.
? Consumption will charge ahead another 7-point-5 percent... while facility investment will leap 15-point-5 percent.
Next year also looks good for the construction sector.?
After contracting sharply this year... business will pick up... to put the industry back in the positive terroritory in the five percent range.
And on inflation... Korea is looking at posting 3-point-1 percent next year.
? In the meantime... researchers say... Korea will wrap up 19-99... with a gross domestic product of 10-point-2 percent... thanks to strong growth in the final months.? 
The B-O-K''s head researcher explains this year''s astounding performance is largely due to inventories being cleared... a factor the economy will have to do without next year.?

? Controversy is mounting following Japan''s announcement that two of its citizens had moved their family registers to Tokdo (독도)... ? the island in the East Sea... claimed by both Korea and Japan.
The Japanese call the tiny islet... "Takeshima".
According to K-B-S... Tokyo notified Seoul that two Japanese nationals had listed Tokdo on their family registers... an act which some people in Korea interpret as Japan''s attempt to claim sovereignty over the island.
Korea currently has control of Tokdo.
Government officials in Seoul reportedly issued a verbal note of regret over the incident... not a written document...
And this has angered civic groups in the country... demanding the government do more... and take a stronger stance regarding the island.?
artcl_titl: 독도에 일본호적#Japanese nationals move family registers to Ttokto#
artcl_titl_en: 독도에 일본호적#Japanese nationals move family registers to Ttokto#

artcl_ctt:
? The government won''t make a decision... ? on whether or not to place Daewoo Corporation under court receivership... until late January.
The extra time will be used to continue negotiations... between Daewoo''s domestic and foreign creditors.
Last week... the foreign banks turned down a proposal by their Korean counterparts... which entailed an average loan repayment rate of 34 percent.
The overseas lenders are demanding recovery of an average 59 percent of their loans to Daewoo affiliates.?
artcl_titl: (주)대우 법정관리 3~4주 유보#Decision on Daewoo Corp. put off till Jan.#
artcl_titl_en: (주)대우 법정관리 3~4주 유보#Decision on Daewoo Corp. put off till Jan.#

artcl_ctt:
? It''s time now as always to quickly check the stories being covered by the local dailies...

? Five days left until the new year...
This has governments, businesses, and individuals anxiously preparing for possible Y-2-K computer problems.
People are lining up at banks to withdraw cash... buying basic necessities like bottled water... and stocking up on emergency medicine.

Meantime... local governments are actively pursuing a marketing strategy... aimed at developing and exporting their region''s brand goods.
The southern city of Pusan has Tezroc(테즈락)... while Taegu has Chemeric (쉬메릭).
The two brands cover a wide-range of products... from clothing to... accessories... such as umbrellas.
Officials report exports at more than a million dollars so far.
Both brands have been boosted by a joint promotion campaign sponsored by the provincial governments.

Finally... the nation''s institutes of higher learning have announced the first batch of the class of 2000.
Among them... nineteen year old Park Ji-hyo(박지효) who studied with the help of his devoted family and understanding friends and teachers.
Park is paralyzed and can only use three fingers to write.
Despite his disabilities... Park received a high score on the scholastic aptitude test.
He''s been accepted to the prestigious engineering school at Hanyang University.

And as OUR top story this morning... a message from the President.?

? The United States topped the list of places Koreans would like to travel to... if given a chance.
Of 15-hundred people surveyed by the Korea National Tourism Organization... 43-percent picked the U-S as their favorite tourist destination.
A closer look at the poll''s results... in this report.

? This year, more Koreans want to travel to the United States than any other place in the world.
The Korea National Tourism Organization polled some 15-hundred Koreans recently... asking them to pick their favorite tourist destination.
43-point-5 percent chose the U-S.
This is a different picture from 19-95... when most Koreans selected Europe and in 19-97... when they chose Australia as the number one tourist spot.
? Following the U-S as the favorite... 39-percent of the pollees picked Australia... then Japan with 31-percent... Canada at 28-percent and France with 27-percent ?... of places they would like to visit.
Those were some of the places Koreans WANTED to visit...
In reality, though... more Koreans traveled to Japan than any other destination.
Of the outbound passengers... ? 30-percent of Koreans in the survey headed to Japan... 27-percent went to China... and 11-percent landed in Thailand.?
As for expenses... Koreans spent on average 1-point-6 million won, or 13-hundred dollars... for each trip outside the country.
Another interesting fact from the survey... 63-percent of the respondents made more than 4 trips abroad in their lifetime.
Koreans are travelling more frequently now... compared to two years ago... at the height of the economic crisis.?
artcl_titl: 한국 여행객, "미국 가장 가고 싶다"#Koreans pick US as favorite tourist destination#
artcl_titl_en: 한국 여행객, "미국 가장 가고 싶다"#Koreans pick US as favorite tourist destination#

artcl_ctt:
? Time Magazine has picked Albert Einstein as the Person of the Century.
Here now is a closer look at the science genius... and his contributions... to the 20th century... dubbed as the age of technology.

? Albert Einstein was born in Ulm, Germany in 1879.
His General Theory of Relativity described gravity as the warping of space and time, changing our view of the universe.
Einstein theories are paramount in modern physics, authoring the famous equation E equals M-C squared.
He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.
In 1933, Einstein fled Germany as Hitler and the Nazis were seizing power and settled in Princeton, New Jersey, where he helped establish a group to re-settle refugees, the International Rescue Committee.
During World War two, he helped America to develop the first atomic bombs which were used to end the war.
? "Einstein in a sense was a humanitarian too and could see the impact of the things he did and he had a foreboding sense of what some of his breakthroughs would do but science is not only a pure laboratory based kind of thing, but it also opens the door to social change and the evolution of ideas.
If you look at the world today, at the idea of democracy spreading... I don''t think that could''ve happened without technology."
Time magazine describes Einstein as the greatest mind and paramount icon of our age.
His theories laid the groundwork for technologies from television to space travel.
Einstein passed away in Princeton, New Jersey in 1955 at the age of 87.?

? Local financial markets are getting an early start to the year end holidays...
They''re closing their doors this afternoon.
As you know... the KOSPI jumped 14 points to retake the one thousand mark yesterday.
And this has left many wondering... just how high will investor spirits hit today in Seoul?
In the meantime... this morning... we''re going to take a look back at the KOSPI''s superb run this year... soaring nearly 70 percent.

? The Korea Stock Exchange will wrap up a banner year of trading Tuesday... in color.
With brokers'' order slips no longer needed on the computerized exchange... bright-colored confetti will be showered on the trading floor instead... to keep with tradition at the closing ceremony.
The benchmark Korean Composite Stock Price Index Monday''s session ... at 1-thousand-and-five points.
It''s the tenth time so far this year the key index closed above the one-thousand mark.
That''s also a 70 percent leap from January''s opening of under 590.
The boom is attributed to renewed interest in local stocks... especially among foreign investors in line with the economic recovery.
The emergence of mutual and stock funds also drew individual investors... and led to an explosive growth in online stock trading.
The biggest factor perhaps... can be found in the over-the-counter KOSDAQ market. 
Investor confidence in technology stocks... drove the benchmark index up some 240-percent from the start of this year.
Not everyone''s getting a joyride ... though.
Even while the KOSPI hovered around the one-thousand mark... over 20-percent of the listed shares plunged to their annual lows.?
artcl_titl: #Domestic Bourse to Finish Stellar Year in Colored Paper#
artcl_titl_en: #Domestic Bourse to Finish Stellar Year in Colored Paper#

artcl_ctt:
? And hoping to spread the joys of the coming new year... and peace on the Korean peninsula...
? Seoul''s Ewha Womans University hosted a unique event yesterday... to feed the hungry in both South and North Korea.
More than 500 people... including Seoul Mayor Koh Gun... faculty and students... gathered for the rice cake festival... which had all the participants making and cutting some twenty tons of Ga-rae-dduk (가래떡).
That''s the rice cake used in the traditional New Year''s soup.
Made from rice donated by various civic groups... the rice cakes will be distributed around the nation and sent to the North... early next month.
What''s more... the rice cake made yesterday was the longest in the world... at 350 meters.
Organizers of the charity festival plan to have the rice cake recorded in the Guiness Book of Records.?

? Prosecutors plan to summon president of Asiana Airlines... Park Sam-ku(박삼구)... as early as today... amid allegations of stock price manipulation.
? His brother... the Kumho Group chairman... is also expected to be called in soon for questioning.
The brothers are accused of illegally pocketing profits worth more than 900-million won... by tampering with the conglomerate''s share prices last April.
Prosecutors last night questioned the head of Kumho Petrochemical, Park Chan-koo (박찬구)... who allegedly bought five-million shares in Kumho Tire... before the official announcement of the company''s merger with the Group''s construction unit.
Through the deal... Park raked in 11 million dollars in profits.
Prosecutors looking into the case say... they have enough evidence to file charges.?
artcl_titl: 금호그룹, 주가조작 사법처리 예정#Kumho owners charged with share price manipulation#
artcl_titl_en: 금호그룹, 주가조작 사법처리 예정#Kumho owners charged with share price manipulation#

artcl_ctt:
? Hope your week is off to a good start.
Here are Monday''s top stories.

? At the presidential house tonight... a special gathering... to assess the achievements of 19-99... and... prepare for the future.

? In the hot seat this week... the founding family of the Kumho Group... for violating stock transaction laws.

? Also today... a call to stop issuing currency stabilization bonds... amid rising concerns about inflation.?

? And before we go... with just two more trading sessions left... including today''s...
? Local stocks have jumped almost thirty points... to recover the one thousand mark.
The won meantime is trading flat... at 11-32 point-5 per U-S dollar.

That is our report at this hour.
We hope you''ll stay with Arirang TV throughout the day.
Thank you for watching.?
? Hello and welcome to Biz.Today.?

? The investigation into the crash of the Korean Air cargo plane in Britain... ? is reportedly being delayed because the flight data recorder is missing.
Investigators are said to have found the underwater locator beacon, a part of the flight data recorder... but the device itself has yet to be found.
British authorities, meanwhile, have dismissed the possibility of terrorism as the cause of the crash...
According to the cockpit voice recorder found earlier... the plane may have experienced technical problems before it went down.?
artcl_titl: KAL,정밀 재조사#Update on KAL cargo crash probe#
artcl_titl_en: KAL,정밀 재조사#Update on KAL cargo crash probe#

artcl_ctt:
? President Kim Dae-jung is hosting a dinner for his predecessors... this evening.
? At Chongwadae right now... are ? ex-presidents Choi Kyu-hah, Chun Doo-hwan, and Roh Tae-woo... as well as Prime Minister Kim Jong-pil, Chief Justice Choi Jong-young, and National Assembly Speaker Park Jun-kyu.
Former President Kim Young-sam has turned down the invitation... citing personal reasons.
During the dinner... President Kim is expected to look back on this year''s stronger-than-expected economic recovery... and explain his diplomatic achievements.
He''s also believed to have asked the others... to play a leading role in rooting out regionalism.?
artcl_titl: 전직 대통령 오늘 청와대 만찬#Chongwadae dinner for ex-presidents#
artcl_titl_en: 전직 대통령 오늘 청와대 만찬#Chongwadae dinner for ex-presidents#

artcl_ctt:
? The National Assembly''s special session is likely to resume normal operations today.
? The session has been sitting idle... due ?to political bickering over the opposition''s demand to have an independent counsel look into allegations that the government tried to control the media.
The Assembly still has some 50 pending bills on public welfare... which need to be handled before the end of this year.?
artcl_titl: 임시국회 오늘 정상화될듯#NA to return to normal#
artcl_titl_en: 임시국회 오늘 정상화될듯#NA to return to normal#

anc_ment_ctt:
?@ Let's now look deeper into the campaign pledges made by the two leading presidential candidates,... this time on solving the nation's household debt problem... which has been dragging down the local economy.
Hwang Ji-hye (황지혜) has more.
artcl_ctt:
?@ Korea's household debt has hit a critical point,... with the accumulated debt rising to 164 percent of disposable income last year -- much higher than the U.S. figure at the beginning of the subprime mortgage crisis.
It's no surprise... that the country's household debt problem has become such a major issue in this year's election.

(Korean)
?@?@?@ "Pre-emptive measures are crucial to solving the household debt problem."

?@ The Saenuri Party's Park Geun-hye... if she becomes President Park... wants to create a fund to ease the debt burden for the 3-point-2 million people who are unable to repay their loans.
Her "National Happiness Fund" is worth 18 trillion won,... or roughly 17 billion U.S. dollars. ?@
She plans to finance it through bonds worth 1-point-7 billion dollars... in a credit recovery fund and a delinquent loan fund.
?@ Park would also reduce the interest rates on loans of up to around 93-hundred dollars -- from 20 percent to 10 percent. ?@ 
She would also give borrowers more time to repay their loans.
Experts meanwhile,... have doubts about the feasibility of the plan.

(Korean)
?@	?@
?@ "Park Geun-hye's plan for reducing household debt could create a moral hazard, as the government, not the borrowers, will be responsible for repaying the borrowers' debt.
Park's plans are also quite unrealistic, because the government will have to issue bonds that are ten times greater than their original value."

(Korean).
?@ ?@?@ "The household debt problem should be solved with the premise that debtors are also precious human beings."

Moon's plans for tackling the problem fall under what he calls the "The 3 Pieta Acts," named for the movie "Pieta,"... which depicts the brutal consequences of dealing with loan sharks.
Under the plan, the Interest Limitation Act would be revised and two new laws would be created -- the Fair Lending Act and the Fair Debt Collection Act.
?@ The Interest Limitation Act aims to lower the interest rates on loans from 39 percent to 25 percent annually.
Under the Fair Lending Act, financial institutions would have to strengthen their assessments of borrowers' repayment capabilities.
And under the Fair Debt Collection Act, lenders would be prohibited from making "unreasonable visits" for debt collection.?@
Moon's plans, experts say, also have their weak points. 

(Korean)
?@?@?@ "Some institutions won't lend money to borrowers at low interest rates when there is a risk they could lose money. So if the government limits interest rates, there is a risk that borrowers will be forced to turn to even more brutal loan sharks."

?@ However,... some experts say... that the candidates' plans for dealing with household debt could be realized with a few corrections and the establishment of long-term measures to solve the issue.
Hwang Ji-hye, Arirang News. ?@

artcl_ctt:
? The local stock market rose for the fourth consecutive day to regain the one-thousand mark this Monday.
The benchmark KOSPI picked up 14 points to ? end the trading day at one-thousand-five.
Telecommunications shares led the rally... with state-run Korea Telecom jumping 15 percent to a record 171-thousand-500 won.
The nation''s top five telecom-related shares... including Korea Telecom, SK Telecom and Dacom... make up 45 percent of the market capital.
231-million shares changed hands on turnover of four trillion won. 
Decliners led advancers by a five to three margin... while 56 issues stayed put.
35 shares hit their daily limit highs... and 32 sank to their lows.
Here now... is a look at some major stocks.?

?There''s a trend in the corporate sector... albeit small now... that''s starting to make people notice different ways to create a work environment... that''s creative and efficient.
Yon Seong-hun has the story.

? Cheiljedang.
A Korean conglomerate that has its beginnings in foodstuffs... and later... pharmaceuticals... and most recently the movie industry.
Associated with big brands like Gatorade and Dreamworks... it''s now undergoing a facelift... from this... to this.
At corporate headquarters... one executive took time out to talk about some of the changes taking place.
? ("One of the most deeply-felt changes is in the 
?use of honorifics. Until recently corporate titles such as Kwajangnim (manager) were used to refer to each other. That''s replaced with a simple ''Nim''. There was some awkwardness and difficulties at first, but now it''s widely accepted.")
Just a tip though... of a fast-moving iceberg... to bring on a revolution in corporate life.
 As the V-P''s own attire would attest... gone are the days of stiff suits and ties to be replaced by... well just about anything goes.
Flexible work hours... compensation by accurate performance evaluation... and a renewed emphasis on roles rather than hierarchy... put into effect in the past few months.
A rejection perhaps... of a decades-old legacy on uniformity and top-down management... that many have pointed out as one of the causes leading to a crippled economy in 19-98.
It''s designed to get the creative juices flowing... in an atmosphere more akin perhaps to Silicon Valley.
? "People want to express themselves and people ?that are younger that''s coming into the company wants to express more of themselves. And by having dress codes and all this formal titles and everything will keep them boxed. By destroying that everybody will be able to be more creative."
A typical Korean conglomerate... moving forward with changes... not so typical.
Yon Seong-hun, Arirang T-V.?
artcl_titl: KTW Korean Corporations Face Culture Changes
artcl_titl_en: KTW Korean Corporations Face Culture Changes

artcl_ctt:
? A local venture company says it''s developed a cellular phone that''s able to identify its user.. by recoginizing his or her finger print.
Here''s more on what it does.

? The modern day reliance on credit cards and automated cash dispensers really stem from one need... identifying the individual.
One Korean venture company thinks it''s created the one thing that''ll eventually rid the world of passwords and door locks.
Think of it as a cellular phone that''s really a master key... or Pass Phone... as the product is called.
The developer... Pass 21st Century ... claims the technology is completely error-free unlike previous finger-print recognition equipment.
Such equipment commonly saw limitations in recognizing damaged tissue ... and were always susceptible to good fakes.
Pass 21st says.... their technology looks a little closer at finger tips... closer that is... on the genetic level and therefore can only be fool-proof.
The result is a cell-phone that can ... for example .... communicate with cash or credit card machines... toll booths, computerized locks or any number of secured facilities... to provide the user with services based on confirmed identity.
The company says mass production of the wonder phone... is just six months away... to be taken up by the nation''s top electronics maker... Samsung.
?

? A local venture company says it''s developed the world''s first cellular phone that identifies the user through his or her finger print.
? The developer... Pass 21st Century... claims the technology is competely error-free... and would make it impossible for others to fake the user''s identity.
The phone can be used to replace a wide range of functions that require personal identification... such as transactions using credit cards or electronic cash.
It could even do away with dependence on keys.
The company says Samsung Electronics has agreed to begin mass-producing the wonder phone... starting next June.?
artcl_titl: (cp) pass phone#Korean firms develops pass phone#
artcl_titl_en: (cp) pass phone#Korean firms develops pass phone#

artcl_ctt:
? Efforts to end the hostage situation on an Indian Airlines plane... have hit a snag.
? Negotiations between the hijackers and U-N officials broke down after an hour Sunday... securing the release of just one hostage.
160 passengers remain on board.
Authorities in Afghanistan... where the plane IS at this time... are blaming India''s lukewarm attitude for the failed talks.
The hijackers are demanding the release of a Pakistani religious leader, and several Kashmiri fighters.
Although determined not to give into terrorism... the Indian government says it is studying several options.
Five armed hijackers seized the plane, Friday... after it took off from Nepal to go to India.?
artcl_titl: 피납 인도 여객기 협상 결렬# No Progress in Indian Airline Hijack #
artcl_titl_en: 피납 인도 여객기 협상 결렬# No Progress in Indian Airline Hijack #

artcl_ctt:
?Last summer... we brought you a story about a community service group... that builds houses for the needy.
The report was about the group''s first project in Seoul.
Well... months of round-the-clock work have now produced a very precious fruit of labor... seen in this report by Shim Miryung.

? The number of houses in Korea has doubled to 9 million in the past 20 years.
But for those without the means... owning a house can be a struggle.
It''s for these people that Habitat for Humanity Korea has been building homes for.
??"I''m so happy this Seoul Habitat house worked out, because it''s difficult to build a house in the capital.  But with the effort of 400 people, we made it..."?
The house... though... is not free.
It comes with price called sweat equity... around 500 hours of labor going into the building.
The owners also have to pay back the construction fee of 20-million won or 17-thousand U-S dollars, over a 15 year period, at no-interest.
Thirty two families applied for the Seoul Habitat home out of which five... including Kim Soo-young, were selected.
??("I want to hand over this gift from God to others in need as we were, as soon as things get better for us.") ?   
?	"I''m so happy. I want to invite my friends and have a party."
Kim... who worked 700 hours... more than the required amount, even hurt his waist... but has never felt happier.
More than four-hundred volunteers, including students and professionals also helped out.
The century''s last Christmas will be especially meaningful for the five families... whose dreams of owning their own homes have finally come true through Habitat.
Shim Miryung, Arirang TV."?

? Among the nation''s public servants... policemen were found to be the least fit.
? This is based on health checkups conducted last year on 1-point-3 million civil workers including teachers.
Members of the armed forces are said to be the fittest... scoring the highest on average... with 57 percent.
Those in the police force scored below normal health standards... at 41 percent.?

artcl_ctt:
? Many concerts were held around Seoul in time for Christmas... but the one featured in our next story stood out.
Why?
Because... the stage was set up at a soy sauce factory.
Rah Seungyun picks up this story.

? Soy sauce and rock music .... it''s not the most likely combination.
But its very unlikeliness could be the fact which drew two thousand young people to an old soy-sauce factory on the out-skirts of Seoul.
The brainchild of two old friends... the Seng Seng Variety Show... meaning Fresh Variety Show... is an attempt to bring the old, closer to the new.
The old in this case, is the Sempio Foods Company.
The company is planning to move its operations to another location, and in commemoration, decided to throw a party for the young.
??"Our company is fifty years old, and is very 
?well-known to the older generation.  We decided to offer a playground for youngsters to have fun in their own terms, we can come close to the younger generation."
It wouldn''t have been so easy, without the help of a super-hip, young brand... called Ssamzie.
??Sempio conjures up our grandmother''s cooking, ? our traditional taste.  And it''s something that Ssamzie, which is only about 15 years old, has grown up on."
Park and the president of the leather goods store are school buddies, and when they were reunited last summer after three decades.... they decided to create a new, unique cultural scene.
This concert is their second joint project... they had held another concert at a local university this past fall.
The main purpose of these events may just be a marketing strategy... trying to approach tomorrow''s consumers on their grounds... but for those enjoying the concert .... it really doesn''t seem to matter all that much.
Rah Seungyun, Arirang TV.?

? Turning to market action elsewhere in the region...

Japan''s Nikkei 225 lost 38 points to close just under 18-thousand-547.
Lenders such as the Industrial Bank of Japan and Sakura Bank... paced the fall.
Analysts say investors sold their shares... to reduce their holdings and minimize their exposure to possible Y2K problems.?

? Markets in Hong Kong and Sydney are closed this Monday.

On the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange... the Composite Index rose three-tenths of a percent... to end the trading day at 785.
Investors there are becoming bullish with Prime Minister Mahathir predicting the economy could grow by more than five percent next year.

South of Malaysia in Singapore... the Straits Times index added on almost 14 points to finish at 24-60.
This... after another gain overnight on the NASDAQ market.

And in Taiwan, the key index rose 195 points to 84-15... spurred by retail investors'' interest in semiconductor shares.

And now... the exchange rates.?

? Shifting tectonic plates ripped and shattered lives around the globe this year...
The most devastating were... Turkey''s pair of earthquakes... three months apart...
18-thousand people were killed... while tens of thousands of others were injured and made homeless.
Numerous aftershocks followed as well... some of them... strong enough to be called earthquakes in their own right.
And on this side of the globe... in Taiwan, some 24-hundred died... as thousands of buildings crumbled.
That quake... measuring 8-point-7 on the Richter scale... was described as the strongest to hit the island nation in a century.?

? Now let''s get a check of tomorrow''s weather for Korea and elsewhere.?

? That is all from us this evening.
Thank you for watching.?

? In the coming year... President Kim Dae-jung says greater efforts need to be made to... bring about political stability.
? His comments came in a meeting with his top aides at Chongwadae Sunday... the last such gathering for this year.
President Kim said political stability is key to attracting foreign investment and improving inter-Korean ties.
Kim also stressed the need to handle social issues...
The president pointed out the government should work harder to lower the jobless rate in the new year... and reduce the gap between the rich and the poor.?

? Two years of restructuring have changed the nation''s coporate sector...
For example... it''s drastically changed the way Korean firms manage their business.
Now... it''s about creating a work environment... that encourages more creativity to boost efficiency.
Here''s Yon Seong-hun.

? Cheiljedang.
A Korean conglomerate that has its beginnings in foodstuffs... and later... pharmaceuticals... and most recently the movie industry.
Associated with big brands like Gatorade and Dreamworks... it''s now undergoing a facelift... from this... to this.
At corporate headquarters... one executive took time out to talk about the winds of change.
? ("One of the most deeply-felt changes is in the use of honorifics. Until recently corporate titles such as Kwajangnim (manager) were used to refer to each other. That''s replaced with a simple ''Nim''. There was some awkwardness and difficulties at first, but now it''s widely accepted.")
Just a tip though... of a fast-moving iceberg... to bring on a revolution in corporate life.
? As the V-P''s own attire would attest... gone are the days of stiff suits and ties to be replaced by... well just about anything goes.
Flexible work hours... compensation by accurate performance evaluation... and a renewed emphasis on roles rather than hierarchy... put into effect in the past few months.
A rejection perhaps... of a decades-old legacy of uniformity and top-down management... that many have pointed out as one of the causes leading to a crippled economy last year.
It''s designed to get the creative juices flowing... in an atmosphere more akin perhaps to Silicon Valley.

? A typical Korean conglomerate... moving forward with changes... not so typical.
Yon Seong-hun, Arirang T-V.?

? A local think tank says North Korea''s economy is on the road to recovery... after hitting rock bottom last year.
? The Korea Development Institute is citing... a report by Kang Duk-joo(강덕주)... a Korean-Japanese who visited the communist country this past January.
Kang says... with the near completion of a hydroelectric power plant... the North''s machinery, transport, and chemical industries are picking up.
He adds Pyongyang is aggressively planning to restore the nation''s economy to the 19-80s level... by the year 2002.
North Korea''s economy peaked back in the 80s, before a series of natural disasters sent the agricultural sector into a freefall, leading to widespread starvation.?
artcl_titl: 북 경제 회복국면 접어들어 # NK Economy Shows Signs of Recovery #

artcl_ctt:
? One of the world''s greatest spectacles to usher in the new millennium is promised at the Great Pyramids of Egypt.
One thousand artists will take to the stage in a special concert... with thousands more watching.
We get a look at the preparations underway... in this report.

? Thousands of years after they were completed, Egypt''s Great Pyramids are surrounded once again by construction workers.
Builders are putting the final touches to the stage for a performance that comes just once a millennium.
A 15-hundred square meter stage is needed for the one thousand Egyptian and international artists who will perform before the Pyramids.
Spectacular lighting effects are being installed to better highlight the pyramids.... 
The event kicks off at sunset on New Year''s Eve... with light music, followed by a two and a half hour concert by French composer Jean Michel Jarre.
?"... the pyramids are probably the best location to think about time and to relate with time and I think as we all know when you are in front of the pyramids, you are not in front of the past, but you are in front of the idea of time, the idea of also where a lot of people think that everything began."
Egypt, which has 6 thousand years of recorded history, is promoting the event as the beginning of the 7th millennium.
80 international television channels will be broadcasting the event live... and some 75-hundred people are expected to pay 400 US dollars each for a seat at the performance.
50-thousand others will have to pay 14 and a half dollars for standing room.
But with less than a week left until the New Year, most of tickets to the extravaganza are sold, and those that are left, are selling fast.?
artcl_titl: Egypt, Pyramids # Egypt Prepares for Millennium Party #
artcl_titl_en: Egypt, Pyramids # Egypt Prepares for Millennium Party #

artcl_ctt:
? The government plans to invest four-trillion won or about three-billion US dollars in the country''s venture firms next year.
? The Ministry of Finance and Economy says the government will set up a venture support firm next April... to boost the competitiveness of start-up companies.
And in May... Seoul will invest another 4-and-a-half billion won... to build a multi-media technology division as well as a video center.
Officials say the extra support comes as information and telecommunications venture firms emerge as a major driving force of the economy... 
Their net income posted this year a 330 percent jump from a year ago.?

artcl_ctt:
? Russian Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov is expected to visit North Korea late next month.
? According to media reports... Ivanov will likely sign a new treaty with North Korea outlining bilateral relations... to renew their pact which expired four years ago.
Moscow and Pyongyang have reportedly been having problems agreeing on some key issues.
Sources say... unlike the prior agreement... the new treaty will have no reference to Russia''s automatic military intervention... in case of an emergency on the Korean peninsula.?

? Kangwon Province was the destination of choice for thousands of Koreans over this Christmas weekend.
? Some 70-thousand people hit the ski slopes... while 30-thousand others travelled to the Sorak Mountains and other tourists sites in the eastern province.
Heavy snowfall in the region on the day before Christmas... complicated road travels... but that didn''t stop the skiers from making their trip out.?
artcl_titl: 성탄연휴 강원도내 10만 인파 몰려#Thousands flock to Kangwon Province#
artcl_titl_en: 성탄연휴 강원도내 10만 인파 몰려#Thousands flock to Kangwon Province#

artcl_ctt:
? In France... Mother Theresa has been picked as the humanist of this twentieth century.
? One thousand people were surveyed by the French daily... "Le Parisien"...
Results showed 42-percent of the respondents chose the late Mother Theresa... for her devotion to help the needy... in the slums of India.
Also making the list were Father Piere... who gave relief to the poor in France... and Martin Luther King... for his efforts to liberalize African-Americans in the U-S.?

? The investigation into the crash of the Korean Air cargo plane in Britain... ? is reportedly being delayed because the flight data recorder is missing.
Investigators are said to have found the underwater locator beacon, a part of the flight data recorder... but the device itself has yet to be found.
British authorities, meanwhile, have dismissed the possibility of terrorism as the cause of the crash...
According to the cockpit voice recorder found earlier... the plane may have experienced technical problems before it went down.?

? Now to the latest on the Daewoo Group.
The government and domestic creditor banks are expected to finalize debt repayment talks with the foreign banks... by the end of next month.
? Daewoo''s foreign lenders have asked local creditors to buy on average 59-percent of their loan claims...
The domestic creditors have however turned down this request... saying the ratio is some 20-percent too high.
Should talks with the foreign creditors break down, again... some key Daewoo affiliates will most likely be put under court receivership.
The Group''s Corporate Restructuring Coordination Committee is reportedly working right now to minimize the after-effects of such legal action.?
artcl_titl: #Talks with Daewoo''s foreign lenders to wrap up by January#
